docs.abstract: His portrayal of a drill instructor earned him the Oscar for best supporting actor. He was the first Black performer to win in that category.
docs.snippet: His portrayal of a drill instructor earned him the Oscar for best supporting actor. He was the first Black performer to win in that category.
docs.lead_paragraph: Louis Gossett Jr., who took home an Academy Award for “An Officer and a Gentleman” and an Emmy for “Roots,” both times playing a mature man who guides a younger one taking on a new role — but in drastically different circumstances — died early Friday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87.

docs.abstract: Profile of Josh Lucas, actor who plays The Gentleman Caller in Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams's Glass Menagerie; fashion photos (M)
docs.snippet: Profile of Josh Lucas, actor who plays The Gentleman Caller in Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams's Glass Menagerie; fashion photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: By the end of this year, Josh Lucas will have starred in two big-budget Hollywood films -- "Stealth," which Lucas describes as "Top Gun" meets "2001," and "Glory Road," the story of Don Haskins, the Texas Western coach who won the 1966 N.C.A.A. championship with all black starters. "The heat off these movies is huge," Lucas said as he drank a glass of red wine at Mayrose diner in Manhattan. "Everyone in L.A. is saying, 'What do you want?' " His smile suggested a kind of sexy willfulness. "And that's why I'm doing Broadway. Why not run from all this pressure and be on the stage in 'The Glass Menagerie' for the next five months?"

headline.print_headline: STYLE; A Gentleman Comes to Call

docs.abstract: A sequel to “Gone With the Wind” sets out to restore the reputation of Rhett Butler.
docs.snippet: A sequel to “Gone With the Wind” sets out to restore the reputation of Rhett Butler.
docs.lead_paragraph: Midway through Donald McCaig’s unexpectedly diverting novel, “Rhett Butler’s People,” a black man about to be lynched in the post-bellum South asks Rhett to please shoot him dead before the mob breaks into the jail and does worse. Rhett obliges. Thus does McCaig correct the record. In Margaret Mitchell’s telling — that is, in “Gone With the Wind” — we learn that Rhett has been arrested for killing “this darky who had insulted a white woman.” A few chapters later, Rhett confesses his guilt to Scarlett O’Hara, the other half of Mitchell’s famous romantic pair. “What else could a Southern gentleman do?” he asks.

docs.abstract: Profile of actor Peter O'Toole, who will receive honorary Oscar at age of 70, after seven nominations; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Profile of actor Peter O'Toole, who will receive honorary Oscar at age of 70, after seven nominations; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IT is fitting that the fastidious Peter O'Toole (bookmaker's son turned gentleman) should have led us to reconsider the etiquette of that shame-faced award, the honorary Oscar. How lovely, he said, that at the age of 70 and with seven unrequited nominations on his record, he should now be on the receiving end of the academy's mortified politeness.

headline.print_headline: OSCAR FILMS; Survivor, Philosopher, Gentleman, Star

docs.abstract: Wild boy Mowgli turns heartthrob. Nice diversion.
docs.snippet: Wild boy Mowgli turns heartthrob. Nice diversion.
docs.lead_paragraph: Brashly panoramic in the candy-colored style of a children's story book, the newest film incarnation of Rudyard Kipling's "Jungle Book" is a movie that is absolutely clear in what it wants to say. Human beings may think they're better than animals, but they are probably worse, since animals kill only for food. Those who do not seek to live in harmony with nature risk being devoured by nature. Greed is bad, especially when it involves exploiting the jungle.

headline.main: Mowgli as Heartthrob And Young Gentleman
headline.print_headline: FILM REVIEW; Mowgli as Heartthrob And Young Gentleman

docs.abstract:
IN A TIMES SQUARE LOFT, THE actor-turned-director Charles Repole (in photo at right) is noticeably giddy -- if not ready to jump on stage and do all the parts. Instead, the elfin director lip-syncs while his cast belts out "It's High Time," an up-tempo anthem celebrating alcoholic beverages. It is the opening number of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," the 1949 musical based on the novel by Anita Loos with a score by Jule Styne. 

Everyone knows "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," or at least one delicious bit from it, the song "Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend." The show ran for 740 performances, made Carol Channing a star and later became a film vehicle for Marilyn Monroe. It has not been revived on Broadway until now. Mr. Repole's production is being presented by the National Actors Theater -- its only offering this season -- in association with the Goodspeed Opera House of East Haddam, Conn., where the show played last winter. In previews at the Lyceum Theater, it opens on April 10 with a cast that includes KT Sullivan, Karen Prunzik, Allen Fitzpatrick and Jamie Ross.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN A TIMES SQUARE LOFT, THE actor-turned-director Charles Repole (in photo at right) is noticeably giddy -- if not ready to jump on stage and do all the parts. Instead, the elfin director lip-syncs while his cast belts out "It's High Time," an up-tempo anthem celebrating alcoholic beverages. It is the opening number of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," the 1949 musical based on the novel by Anita Loos with a score by Jule Styne.

docs.abstract: I must report this for posterity, which will want to know. The late Abe Burrows, the great big bear-hug of an Abe Burrows, was - as a writer for the theater -absolutely incorrigible. He simply would not play by the rules.   Take the matter of opening nights. I mean his own opening nights, when a ''Guys and Dolls'' or a ''How to Succeed'' was about to unleash itself upon polite society. The rules for opening nights insist that the author -whether he wrote the whole shebang or perhaps just the libretto - be, for the moment, The Invisible Man.   He is not supposed to be out on the sidewalk, watching the stretch limousines disgorge their unrecognizable celebrities. He is not even supposed to be just outside the stage door, taking a forbidden drag on a cigarette and nodding nervously at total strangers.
docs.lead_paragraph: I must report this for posterity, which will want to know. The late Abe Burrows, the great big bear-hug of an Abe Burrows, was - as a writer for the theater -absolutely incorrigible. He simply would not play by the rules.

headline.main: FAREWELL TO A JAUNTY GENTLEMAN OF THE STAGE
headline.print_headline: STAGE VIEW;   FAREWELL TO A JAUNTY GENTLEMAN OF THE STAGE

docs.abstract: Naval trainees and Puget Sound debs. Gritty and persuasive.
docs.snippet: Naval trainees and Puget Sound debs. Gritty and persuasive.
docs.lead_paragraph: THE hero of ''An Officer and a Gentleman'' is neither of those things when the movie begins, but he is both by the time it is over. In this resolutely old-fashioned Navy tale, a selfish, hard-hearted loner becomes a much, much better man, thanks to the rigors of basic training and the love of a good woman. Undeniably, there's an element of corniness to this. But that doesn't keep ''An Officer and a Gentleman'' from being a first-rate movie - a beautifully acted, thoroughly involving romance. If this summer hasn't previously had a wonderful Hollywood love story to call its own, it has one now.

headline.main: 'OFFICER AND A GENTLEMAN,' NAVY LOVE STORY
headline.print_headline: 'OFFICER AND A GENTLEMAN,' NAVY LOVE STORY

docs.abstract: Ticket sales for “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” have been strong since it was nominated for 10 Tonys.
docs.snippet: Ticket sales for “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” have been strong since it was nominated for 10 Tonys.
docs.lead_paragraph: After the Tony Award winners are announced on Sunday night, what will happen to ticket sales for two of Broadway’s most-nominated musicals, “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” and “After Midnight”?

headline.main: Strong Sales for ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ Ahead of Tony Awards

docs.abstract: "THE GENTLEMAN TRAMP," opening today at the New Yorker and other theaters, is an authorized documentary devoted to the life of Charlie Chaplin. The film, which was made sometime before the great man's death last year, carries the information that "every frame, from rough cut to final version, has been checked and approved personally by Charles Chaplin." Like all authorized biographies, it's somewhat too pious for its own good humor.The film was directed, written and edited by Richard Patterson, who worked with Peter Bogdanovich on the 1972. Oscar salute to Chaplin, footage of which is the true climax of the picture. Most of the film is devoted to scenes (many splendid ones) taken from 17 Chaplin comedies, including "City Lights," "The Gold Rush," "Modern Times" and "The Kid."There's an attempt to recapitulate highlights of Chaplin's life—both good times and bad—with newsreel footage, as well as with still photographs, some of which are accompanied by lofty quotations from Chaplin's book, "My Autobiography." The quotations, read by Laurence Olivier, come off worse on film than they do on the printed page: "In Philadelphia I discovered Emerson," says Chaplin, meaning, I suppose, Ralph Waldo. As in "My Autobiography," there's also a good deal of name—or photograph—dropping, to prove that Charlie hobnobbed with swells of his time, including Lloyd George, Winston Churchill and George Bernar Shaw.Some of the film is dreadful, as when we hear a gossip-columnist, who sounds like Hedda Hopper, as she attacks Charlie, but a lot of the comedy footage is still fun, even if out of context. The nicest moments, though, are the home movies in which we see the elderly Charlie and his wife, Oona. They seem to have been a truly happy couple.
docs.lead_paragraph: "THE GENTLEMAN TRAMP," opening today at the New Yorker and other theaters, is an authorized documentary devoted to the life of Charlie Chaplin. The film, which was made sometime before the great man's death last year, carries the information that "every frame, from rough cut to final version, has been checked and approved personally by Charles Chaplin." Like all authorized biographies, it's somewhat too pious for its own good humor.The film was directed, written and edited by Richard Patterson, who worked with Peter Bogdanovich on the 1972. Oscar salute to Chaplin, footage of which is the true climax of the picture. Most of the film is devoted to scenes (many splendid ones) taken from 17 Chaplin comedies, including "City Lights," "The Gold Rush," "Modern Times" and "The Kid."There's an attempt to recapitulate highlights of Chaplin's life—both good times and bad—with newsreel footage, as well as with still photographs, some of which are accompanied by lofty quotations from Chaplin's book, "My Autobiography." The quotations, read by Laurence Olivier, come off worse on film than they do on the printed page: "In Philadelphia I discovered Emerson," says Chaplin, meaning, I suppose, Ralph Waldo. As in "My Autobiography," there's also a good deal of name—or photograph—dropping, to prove that Charlie hobnobbed with swells of his time, including Lloyd George, Winston Churchill and George Bernar Shaw.Some of the film is dreadful, as when we hear a gossip-columnist, who sounds like Hedda Hopper, as she attacks Charlie, but a lot of the comedy footage is still fun, even if out of context. The nicest moments, though, are the home movies in which we see the elderly Charlie and his wife, Oona. They seem to have been a truly happy couple.
